awd_titl_txt: Assessing the Influence of Zero-Deforestation Supply-Chain Commitments on the Conservation of Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
Deforestation has multiple socioenvironmental impacts including land conflict, increasing rural income inequality, biodiversity loss, and hydrological changes.  New conservation policies developed by the private sector are being applied to global supply chains to tackle the challenge of deforestation in the tropics through zero-deforestation commitments.  Yet there is limited knowledge about the impact of these policies or the enabling conditions that may promote their effectiveness.  This project will provide new knowledge on the complex global telecouplings and public-private governance interactions of how zero-deforestation commitments influence land cover change.  The research will enhance our fundamental understanding about the conditions under which zero-deforestation commitments lead to ecosystem conservation.  The research will directly inform public and private environmental policy as well as civil society efforts toward tropical forest conservation. Through open data sharing and archiving, this project will contribute to improving transparency in food supply chains.


This research will study the soy, oil palm, and cattle industries in multiple regions globally and analyze how the socioeconomic and agro-ecological variation across these regions differentially influence outcomes associated with zero-deforestation commitments.  The research will investigate four core questions: 1) Are zero-deforestation policies being applied in the most urgent locations of deforestation? 2) How do corporate zero-deforestation policies interact with public policies to influence agricultural profits and inhibit local incentives to deforest? 3) How do differences in timelines and forest definitions in these policies influence land cover outcomes? and 4) To what degree does leakage of land cover change to other regions offset local reductions in deforestation?  To answer these questions the investigators will collect and synthesize a comprehensive dataset of land cover maps, supply chain commitments, sourcing behaviors, trade flows, and producer costs of compliance or noncompliance with supply chain commitments.  A model will be developed to assess the regional land cover outcomes at a high spatial resolution.  Outcomes from this model with be coupled with existing regional models and a global trade model to evaluate impacts of regional commodity-specific commitments on other commodities and biomes.  The broader implications of this research will help establish the conditions under which zero-deforestation commitments are likely to achieve ecosystem conservation, and inform the development of effective policy mixes across the private and public sectors.

por.por_cntn:
The world continues to lose biodiverse and carbon-rich tropical forests due to the expansion of agriculture for global markets. To help address ongoing deforestation, certain companies that source agricultural products from deforestation-risk areas have made commitments to monitor their supply chains and ensure that their products are not sourced from recently deforested land. This research examined these commitments in the soy and cattle sectors in South America and the oil palm sector in Indonesia. We assessed whether these commitments have reduced deforestation in the regions where they are implemented and how much they could reduce deforestation in other regions where companies have made commitments, but have not yet done anything to implement them. We focused on quantifying how much of the “avoided deforestation” in the targeted areas is offset when deforestations is displaced to areas that are not protected, a process known as “leakage”. We also explored alternative ways, such as through positive incentives, that companies could help encourage zero-deforestation among producers beyond their existing exclusionary approaches. 

We found that corporate implementation of zero deforestation commitments in the Brazilian Amazon has helped reduce forest clearance in the soybean and cattle sectors. These corporate policies threaten to exclude producers who clear their land for these commodities. Reductions in deforestation occur mainly in regions where most of the local commodity production is sourced by a company with an implemented commitment because it gives companies more leverage over farmer behavior. These deforestation reductions in the Brazilian Amazon are not offset by large increases in deforestation in other regions in South America or globally. However, we detected substantial leakage of deforestation to other forested regions within Brazil. We also found that many at-risk forest regions remain unprotected by any form of company commitment due to the limited market coverage of committed firms.  

However, options for protecting new forest areas through supply chain policies are limited and involve tradeoffs. For instance, the strict, exclusionary policies that have been implemented in the Amazon have negative effects on smaller beef cattle producers by forcing them to sell to buyers with less appealing terms of payment. There is limited political support to extend strict exclusionary policies to the Cerrado, a vulnerable forest biome in Brazil that is next to the Amazon but is less protected under Brazilian law and that is also suitable for soy and cattle production. In this region, the soy farmers’ association is quite powerful and has consistently supported a narrative that the Cerrado region has low deforestation risk and large opportunities to expand soy production. This narrative has helped undermine further efforts to limit legal deforestation through corporate commitments. A proposal for a program to pay soy farmers not to clear their land has more support from these farmers, but the potential costs of this policy vastly exceed current financing goals to avoid deforestation. This payment scheme would also exclude communities who have traditionally protected their forests, making it highly inequitable.  

In Indonesia, oil palm is grown both on large industrial plantations run by companies and on smallholder farms. While companies have been responsible for most past deforestation due to oil palm expansion, smallholder farmers also participate in forest clearing. Unlike Brazil, Indonesia does not have complete forest monitoring or property registration and it is expensive for companies to monitor deforestation and link it to individual farmers and their land. As companies with zero deforestation pledges try to fulfill their commitments, they often prioritize traceability and dropping of high-risk suppliers such as smallholders over improving smallholder capacities to stop clearing land. Furthermore, companies sometimes use the potential negative outcomes of zero-deforestation implementation for small farmers as a justification to end further action toward sustainability. They also lobby the government to create policies that would make it more difficult to share information about the sustainability of their products. 

In sum, corporate zero-deforestation commitments for soy and cattle have helped reduced deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon with relatively little leakage to other regions. Yet, such commitments face political or technical challenges elsewhere in Brazil for soy, in Indonesia for oil palm, and where commited companies do not source a majority of the targeted agricultural commodity.
